content.description: Up the left crack, traverse the line of obvious pockets right and finish either up or down the right crack.  Can be done in reverse as well.  Its a big highball with some bad rocks and insecure feet.
content.location: This problem traverses the obvious horizontal line of holds on the Tendon Repair Kit face.

content.description: The original line up the the face is quite scary and committing.  I'll take the dyno any day of the week!  Start on a pocket and grape fuit sloper.  Make a big move to the jug.  Move up and right and the back left past two vertical pockets, finishing past a sloping edge (same holds as the direct.)  Be careful on this one!
content.location: The obvious center line up the Tendon Repair Kit Face.

content.description: Stand-start on a pocket and the grape-fruit sloper.  Make a hard move to a jug.  Set-up and make another BIG move to a sloping crimp.  Finish with a topout and don't jump for the top.
content.location: The obvious line up the center of the Tendon Repair Kit Face.

content.description:
Another soft V5 in the forest. Start sitting just right of the crack on a pinch with a left hand on a pinch on the right side of the crack and a pocket with your right. Move up through a pocket to a jug pocket and finish on the jug horizontal just above it. ( You can top out up and right in the right angle the rocks make and it doesn’t affect the V2 grade. It also doesn’t add much to the route.)

This route is #7a on Boulder 2: Tendon Repair Kit in the Brayack and Keenan Falcon Guidebook.
content.location: Furthest right route on the Tendon Repair Kit Boulder just right of the large vertical crack.

content.description: Contrived.  Start on pockets, and make a big move to the jug.  This problem avoids the crack to the left, but uses a pocket that is basically on the crack.  Really techie and a good problem!
content.location: Just right of the Lightning Crack, which is the left crack on the Tendon Repair Kit Block

content.description: Jam the obvious left crack on the face to either jug (and jump) or to the top.
content.location: The left crack on the Tendon Repair Kit Block

content.description:
Start on the left arete on the trail side of the first boulder in the tendon repair kit area. Traverse the crack to the other arete. At the little tree, start heading up and right to the features on the right arete, then using the arete to top out.  Topout is the only highlight of an otherwise boring route.

This problem is a variation of problem #1 in the Tendon Repair Kit area on Boulder 1 in the Brayack and Keenan falcon guidebook.

To do the original just traverse the crack until you reach the break in the boulders.
content.location: The start of this problem is trailside outside the break in the boulders leading to where the cave problem is. This starts on the left arete of the Boulder and ends on the right arete.

content.description:
Start on the right arete, opposite the finish of Just Plain Lazy (these two aretes form the entrance to the cave that holds Cave Problem).  Traverse right and enjoy a no hands rest on the ledge about halfway through the problem.  Continue traversing past two huecos until you establish on the offwidth crack, then drop off.

This is problem #3 in the Tendon Repair Kit area on Boulder 1 in the Brayack and Keenan falcon guidebook.
content.location: Start on the right arete of the entrance to the cave that holds Cave Problem

content.description: Start on jug a few feet left of the obvious incut flake of "Fin-ish". Power straight up through a few mediocre ledges to slap the top. Topout not recommended.
content.location: Located on The Fin boulder just to the right of the Tendon Repair Kit.

content.description: This problem has multiple different ways of being climbed with two completely different ways of doing the crux. Locate the dark brown jug to the right of the high shelf just below the roof in the cave. This is the ending jug. Either start on a large left hand sidepull directly under the jug or on a flat crimp to the left with a nice finger tip deep divot in it. Figure out your sequence using the crimp, the small sidepull with a horrid thumb-catch, or the double thumb press. Bring your edging shoes because these footholds are (uncharacteristic for sandstone) tiny edges.
content.protection: A single large pad will do.
content.location: This line goes up the smooth blank face inside of the cave to the right of The Cave Problem (V3).

content.description:
This is route #11 on this block in the Falcon guidebook by Brayack and Keenan. The route is unnamed in the book.

Highball. Start on obvious incut flake in the middle of the Fin face.

Power up and right from the flake past a good pocket and a bad pinch up to a good rail. You're not done yet. Cruise through a few easy moves on jugs to finish on a heady, slopey topout.
content.location: Located on The Fin boulder just to the right of the Tendon Repair Kit.

content.description: More like don't look down!  Its pretty easy though.  Follow the finger and hand crack to the top and try not to blow it up high.
content.location: The right crack on the Tendon Repair Kit Block

content.description: Follow the slopey left arete to the top.  You can stop anywhere you want and jump if the cheese gets to stringy.
content.location: On the clean, Tendon Repair Kit Face, this is the left arete

content.description:
Start on the chest/face height holds and continue straight up past an undercling, sidepull, and slopey crimp to a jug before the final hold at the top. Some semi-tricky beta makes this problem easier for some people.

Stays dry in the rain and cool in the summer!
content.protection: 1-2 pads. Safe/flat landing. Spotter may be nice for preventing one from hitting the wall behind the problem.
content.location: Obvious line in the center of the large cave across from Green Block. End matched on the highest jug.
